title: Reconsidering Drugs in Sport
body:
Image: Creative Commons Zero (CCO)

We are all aware that doping in sport is illegal and unfair, but if you were in this situation to be the best athlete as possibly can be, would you take them? Within the society of sport, drugs have become easier and more accessible for the athletes to take, they continue to take them regardless of the consequences that they bring or that WADA (World Anti-Doping Agency) have put into place so that there is no cheating in competitions. The reason why WADA have put these consequences into place is so that competition is sport would be fair for all athletes and for it to be natural. Hughes and Coakley (1991, p. 307) states that “when athletes use the sport ethic, it emphasises sacrifice for the game, seeking distinction, taking risks, and challenging limits as an exclusive guide for behaviour and sports participation to become especially vulnerable to corruption”, meaning that this shows us that the athletes are willing to put their bodies in risk to success highly when participating in competitions. When athletes are participating in competitions, they are regularly reminded by their coach/ medical personnel of their obligation to abide by the anti-doping rules of their sport and that any medical treatment received must not violate these rules.

Drugs are against the rules in sport, but, if we made the drugs legal and freely available, would there be no cheating in sport? However, using drugs within sport, is nothing new, and it is becoming more effective and noticeable in younger individuals whom are participating. Jumping back to the history of drugs being used in sport, the emergence was the problem in the 1960’s with the manufacture of synthetic testosterone and that the main critique was that it was inequitable, and it gave the athletes who took them an unfair competitive advantage (Stewart and Smith, 2015).  Also, doping has not always been prohibited in competitive sports, in fact, the Ancient Greeks found it acceptable to use performance-enhancing drugs during the original Olympic Games when it came to be competing for prizes (Guest Blogger, 2016). In the WADA article (10.1), it states that “if an athlete is found to have violated an anti-doping legislation rule during or in preparation for an event, they will be disqualified of all the result obtained in the event and will forfeit any medals, points, and prizes won”.

This relates closely to the doping scandal of Lance Armstrong. Armstrong is a 47-year-old male who was a professional road racing cyclist who previously accomplished in 1999 won the Tour de France. However, 13 years later, he had his titles removed because he was found out that he was doping.

Some critics have suggested that we should legalise all doping and this will then perhaps allow for ‘safe doping’ that could be monitored by accredited doctors. With suggested legalisation of doping drugs, this could reduce the potential harm as they are being properly regulated. Also, critiques have argued against that doping is no more harmful as the intense training regimes that athletes are made to do to show their best performances. Do you think that we should legalise doping?

It is found that more than a third (35%) of amateur sports people say that they personally know others that has doped, and 8% said that they have taken steroids to improve their sporting performance. According to figures from the UK Anti-Doping (UKAD), the agency responsible for protecting clean sport, there are currently 52 athletes and coaches whom are serving a ban from doping in sport. There are health problems when consuming drugs to help performance in sport which are; heart disease, kidney failure and even sudden death. The individuals are not only just cheating in the sport, they are also putting their lives at risk. A single drug test costs around £350, this is to give us information if an athlete is doping, so, should drugs be used in sport?

N0681462

References:

Guest Blogger, (2016). Doping in Sport: Past, Present and Future. Dispute Resolution. [Online Blog]. 2 September 2016. Available at https://blogs.lexisnexis.co.uk/dr/doping-in-sport-past-present-and-future/: URL [Accessed on; 01/11/2018].

Hughes, R. and Coakley, C. (1991). Positive Deviance Among Athletes: The Implications of Over conformity to the Sport Ethic. Sociology of Sport Journal, 8(4), pp, 307-325

Sapstead, N. (2017). Doping in sport: Drug use ‘fast becoming a crisis’. BBC Sport. [Online Blog]. 20 March 2017. Available at https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/38884801. URL [Accessed on; 01/11/2018]

Stewart, B., Smith, A, CT. (2015). Why the war on drugs in sport will never be won. Blog Network. [Online Blog]. 24 November 2015. Available at https://blogs.biomedcentral.com/on-health/2015/11/24/why-the-war-on-drugs-in-sport-will-never-be-won/: URL [Accessed on; 01/11/2018].

Acknowledgements:

Creative Commons Zero (CC0), 2016. Pile of White Pink and Brown Oblong and Round Medication Tablet. Pexels. Available at:https://www.pexels.com/photo/colors-colours-health-medicine-143654/ [Accessed on; 01/11/2018]

title: Itt a titok, emiatt ért el szenzációs sikert a Vidi
body:
A Vidi hazai pályán 1-0-ra legyőzte a görög PAOK-ot, így jelenleg továbbjutásra áll csoortjában a magyar bajnok.

A görög bajnokságot veretlenül vezető PAOK 180 perc alatt egyszer sem tudott betalálni a Vidi kapujába. Marko Nikolics elárulta, mi volt a Vidi győzelmének a kulcsa a csütörtök esti, Groupama Arénában lejátszott mérkőzésen.

Szenzációs győzelmet aratott a Vidi
Fotó: MTI

blog.name: unlevelplayingfield
blog.title: Unlevel Playing Field
blog.description: A sports-related blog curated by final year Sports Education students at Nottingham Trent University

summary: The race that will never be won: revolutionising the stigma around doping in Athletics
title: The race that will never be won: revolutionising the stigma around doping in Athletics
body:
Addicted to winning gold medals and breaking world records – but at what cost? The use of performance enhancing drugs (PEDs) to maximise performance in athletics is as old as the history of the sport itself. In fact, the true prevalence of doping and illicit drug use in contemporary athletics still remains unclear. For example, anonymous surveys carried out at two elite athletics competitions in 2011, found that  57% of competitors admitted doping in the previous 12 months, compared to 4% in tests carried out by the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA). The inconsistencies with the doping data are clear for all to see.


We define the rules of sport and as such it should be our obligation to transform the stigma around doping. The war on drugs in athletics is a long-lost battle, so isn’t it about time we levelled the playing field and made PEDs legal and freely available for all our competitors?

Firstly, we should acknowledge the reasons why athletes may choose to take PEDs. For example, the fact that 30% of competitors at the 2011 IAAF World Championships in Athletics admitted to using banned substances illustrates just how many athletes choose to use PEDs in contemporary athletics. With the use of PEDs only on the rise, it can be expected in the foreseeable future that athletes competing without doping will face near certain disappointment.

Now think about it, how can an athlete receive an unfair advantage if the PEDs are legal and freely available?

Secondly, those who say that drugs undermine the integrity of the sport ought to take a look at the bigger picture and realise that sport isn’t trustworthy, sport isn’t fair, and sport certainly isn’t healthy. Nature isn’t fair for starters. It doesn’t take an expert to know that the unenhanced human body can only take an athlete so far so who are we to stop competitors from taking drugs if they are willing and know the health risks. If anything, genetic engineering helps fair play as it allows all competitors to create an optimal body type for a particular event. There are just so many loopholes in the system, for example: elevating blood count by altitude training or through the use of a hypoxic air machine is exactly the same as taking Erythropoietin, but the latter is still illegal and considered cheating if used.

Thirdly, the idea of ‘winning at all costs’ is deep-rooted in the ethics of athletics and we are confronted with a perverted form of winning because of the pressures put upon athletes to win at all costs. For this reason, the use of PEDs shouldn’t been seen as an inordinate way of winning, and instead should be understood and admired in many ways. As recently as February, the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned lifetime bans on 28 Russian athletes accused of doping, making them eligible to compete in the 2018 Winter Olympics. Perhaps this shows a slight change in thinking from the powers of athletics? Who knows.

Lastly, by all means continue to train assiduously, have the healthiest diet any human being could possibly wish to have and dedicate your entire life to the sport you love but the reality is you are still likely to be second best to the athlete who chooses to dope.

Ask yourself this final question: if you could take a PED that would guarantee you success in your sport, without getting caught, would you take it?

N0679632

References:

BBC. 2014. Sporting Ethics: For Legalisation (online). Available at: http://www.bbc.co.uk/ethics/sport/debate/for.shtml (accessed 1st November 2018)

British Medical Association. 2002. Drugs in Sport: The pressure to perform. London: BMJ Books.

Waddington, I., and Smith, A. 2009. An introduction to Drugs in Sport: Addicted to winning. London: Routledge.

blog.name: unlevelplayingfield
blog.title: Unlevel Playing Field
blog.description: A sports-related blog curated by final year Sports Education students at Nottingham Trent University

title: How Grey is the Juice?
body:
Doping. The word that usually ceases to exist in the vocabulary of the athletes who live ‘by the book’… and when I say by the book…I am referring to the codes, more specifically, the codes of the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), established in 1999. WADA define the occurrence of doping to be breaking the conduct of one or more anti-doping violations located in Article 2.1 of the  World Anti-Doping Code. If, like me, you think that’s a bit too vague… or you don’t have the time to browse through the strenuous text, another definition of doping can be found from the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF)*, who argue that: “Doping is the use of any stimulant not normally employed to increase the poser of action in athletic competition above the average” (IAAF, 2006). The problem with that definition is that it’s hard to define exactly what is ‘above the average’. What is the average? How can we measure this? This is just one example of the many grey areas surrounding the world of doping.  

Another would be in defining what qualifies to be added to the ‘Prohibited List’ – that is… the universal list of banned substances and methods in sport. UK Anti-Doping (UKAD) declare that substances and methods are added to the Prohibited List if they meet at least two of the following criteria:

A) Potential to enhance sports performance

B) Actual or potential health risk to an athlete

C) Its use violates the spirit of sport 

Ok… great! Now that’s been cleared up… or has it? Let’s look at points A) and B). Doesn’t caffeine have the potential to enhance sports performance to some extent? Between 1984 and 2004, caffeine was classed as a performance enhancing drug, and was banned for in-completion uses over a certain dosage. What about the potential health risks of too much caffeine? Interesting…

Let’s try a different combination of criteria… say points A) and C). The WADA code includes the words ‘ethics, fair play and honesty’ as the first point of reference for their definition of the ‘spirit of sport’. So, what about sports equipment? Wouldn’t it be fair to assume that a cyclist with a specialised bike, or a swimmer with an ultra-light swimsuit, may have an unfair advantage over athletes with standard equipment?

What about the difference of economic, social and cultural capital between athletes? Surely higher paid athletes can use their various forms of capital to access elite facilities and sports networks (such as coaches) to enable them to train at a higher standard, and therefore, increase their potential to enhance sports performance… but is this fair? Hmmm….

Here’s a different scenario. As an athlete, what about if you ‘accidentally’ take a banned substance without realising? How can this be proved or disproved? According to Edgar Magazine in 2018, UFC middleweight Anderson Silva, considered one of the greatest fighters of all time, tested positive for steroids in January 2017, following his victory over Nick Diaz in UFC 183. Silva placed the blame on a sexual performance-enhancing drug given to him by a friend…

Do you believe him? Evidently the powers that be didn’t…but would it matter even if they did? Unless they have a crystal ball, it’s impossible to prove.

These are just some of the grey areas that surround the legitimacy of anti-doping policy, however, I think we can all agree that if we’re struggling to perform in the bedroom and we’re involved in competitive sport…it’s probably best not to ask a pal for a little ‘pick me up’. If you absolutely must…make should make sure you read the ingredients label…if there is one.

N0687815

References:

Edgar Magazine. (2018). 10 Famous Athletes Who Were Caught Doping - Edgar Magazine %. [online] Available at: https://edgardaily.com/articles/10-famous-athletes-caught-doping/ [Accessed 8 Nov. 2018].

International Association of Athletics Federations. (2006). IAAF: A Piece of Anti-Doping History: IAAF Handbook 1927-1928| News | iaaf.org. [online] Available at: https://www.iaaf.org/news/news/a-piece-of-anti-doping-history-iaaf-handbook [Accessed 20 Oct. 2018]

Pickering, C. and Kiely, J. (2017). Are the Current Guidelines on Caffeine Use in Sport Optimal for Everyone? Inter-individual Variation in Caffeine Ergogenicity, and a Move Towards Personalised Sports Nutrition. Sports Medicine, [online] 48(1), pp.7-16. Available at: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5752738/ [Accessed 21 Oct. 2018].

World Anti-Doping Agency. (2015). World Anti-Doping Code [online] Available at: https://www.wada-ama.org/sites/default/files/resources/files/wada-2015-world-anti-doping-code.pdf [Accessed 8 Nov. 2018].

WADA define the occurrence of doping to be breaking the conduct of one or more anti-doping violations located in Article 2.1 of the  World Anti-Doping Code. If, like me, you think that’s a bit too vague… or you don’t have the time to browse through the strenuous text, another definition of doping can be found from the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF)*, who argue that: “Doping is the use of any stimulant not normally employed to increase the poser of action in athletic competition above the average” (IAAF, 2006). The problem with that definition is that it’s hard to define exactly what is ‘above the average’. What is the average? How can we measure this? This is just one example of the many grey areas surrounding the world of doping.  

Another would be in defining what qualifies to be added to the ‘Prohibited List’ – that is… the universal list of banned substances and methods in sport. UK Anti-Doping (UKAD) declare that substances and methods are added to the Prohibited List if they meet at least two of the following criteria:

A) Potential to enhance sports performance

B) Actual or potential health risk to an athlete

C) Its use violates the spirit of sport 

Ok… great! Now that’s been cleared up… or has it? Let’s look at points A) and B). Doesn’t caffeine have the potential to enhance sports performance to some extent? Between 1984 and 2004, caffeine was classed as a performance enhancing drug, and was banned for in-completion uses over a certain dosage. What about the potential health risks of too much caffeine? Interesting…

Let’s try a different combination of criteria… say points A) and C). The WADA code includes the words ‘ethics, fair play and honesty’ as the first point of reference for their definition of the ‘spirit of sport’. So, what about sports equipment? Wouldn’t it be fair to assume that a cyclist with a specialised bike, or a swimmer with an ultra-light swimsuit, may have an unfair advantage over athletes with standard equipment?

What about the difference of economic, social and cultural capital between athletes? Surely higher paid athletes can use their various forms of capital to access elite facilities and sports networks (such as coaches) to enable them to train at a higher standard, and therefore, increase their potential to enhance sports performance… but is this fair? Hmmm….

Here’s a different scenario. As an athlete, what about if you ‘accidentally’ take a banned substance without realising? How can this be proved or disproved? According to Edgar Magazine in 2018, UFC middleweight Anderson Silva, considered one of the greatest fighters of all time, tested positive for steroids in January 2017, following his victory over Nick Diaz in UFC 183. Silva placed the blame on a sexual performance-enhancing drug given to him by a friend…

Do you believe him? Evidently the powers that be didn’t…but would it matter even if they did? Unless they have a crystal ball, it’s impossible to prove.

These are just some of the grey areas that surround the legitimacy of anti-doping policy, however, I think we can all agree that if we’re struggling to perform in the bedroom and we’re involved in competitive sport…it’s probably best not to ask a pal for a little ‘pick me up’. If you absolutely must…make should make sure you read the ingredients label…if there is one.
